newsitem.title: FRANCE: France's Chirac failed on campaign pledges - poll.
newsitem.headline: France's Chirac failed on campaign pledges - poll.

text.p: A majority of French voters say that Gaullist President Jacques Chirac failed to keep most of his key 1995 campaign promises, according to a poll published on Friday in the weekly Le Nouvel Economiste.
The CSA survey found that most voters felt he had kept just one promise made during his campaign -- to take France down the path toward European monetary union and a single currency.

On most of his other key pledges -- including lowering taxes, creating jobs, boosting state salaries and an assurance that health care reimbursements would remain uncapped -- most voters judged that he had failed to keep his promises, the poll found.

"Two years after his arrival at the Elysee (presidential palace), Jacques Chirac's performance has little to do with his campaign promises, a gap so flagrant that the president is today obliged -- by the coming legislative election -- to once again establish his legitimacy," the weekly said.
On the question of preparing France for a single European currency, two-thirds of voters felt Chirac had kept his campaign pledge while 16 percent said he had failed and 18 percent had no opinion.
Concerning his pledge to lower taxes, 35 percent said he had kept his promise while 55 percent said he had failed.
And on unemployment, nearly two-thirds said he had failed to honour his promise to reduce unemployment.

Roughly seven in 10 of those polled said they believed that a president must always keep his campaign promises while the remainder felt it was permissible for a president to fall short on his pledges if he felt it was necessary, according to the survey of 1,005 individuals aged 18 and over.
The poll was conducted on April 7-8, well before Chirac announced he was dissolving parliament and calling a snap election for May 25-June 1.
